context_qas.question: What might lead to increases or decreases in Support for Upzoning, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
context_qas.answer: You could increase support for upzoning by actually making these houses super affordable, obviously. You could make the support for upzoning increase exponentially by very much so lowering the property taxes that we are all currently paying in this county. I've mentioned before ours are almost the highest in Georgia, if not the highest, and they go up every year. The influence would be positive if you brought down costs.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Housing affordability on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Yeah, if you advertise, hey, you know, one-bedroom apartments cost $1,800, these new up-zoned buildings are going to cost $1,000 a month, you would have a ton of support for that right away from people who are struggling to afford to live, which is probably over half the country. So in that way, it would be a positive effect by decreasing costs. There is no positive effect for costs going up. People are struggling.

context_qas.question: Does Traffic congestion have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Where I live, traffic congestion was already a big problem. It has become a massive problem over the last seven years. They are building tons of apartment complexes, and they are now starting to upzone, like our Costco is upzoning. The effect on traffic congestion is extremely significant. It definitely decreases support for upzoning, I think, for obvious reasons. One of the main reasons.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Local government role and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The relationship between local government and support for upzoning is direct. I feel like there must be kickbacks or something because our local government completely ignores everyone who lives here, every one of our voices. They completely tune us out and they just approve everything. Tons of gas stations, tons of liquor stores, tons of apartment complexes that literally none of us want. It's a pretty strong connection between local government and upzoning support.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Public opposition lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Well, the public are the ones who have to live with these upzoning changes. So if you don't have public support for upzoning, you're going to have public opposition. They are inverse of each other. Make it affordable, somehow decrease traffic, and you would increase public support. But that's not what they're doing. It's going to remain negative.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Property taxes and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Strong connection. For sure our property taxes are crazy high. They are building all this crap and our property taxes still go up every year. They haven't lowered them at all even though they're bringing in millions more with all the housing that they've built and filled. It's really not fair and they do nothing about it even though we all do use our voice.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Town hall participation lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: It seems to make no difference. We used to have tiny town hall participation, if they even held town halls. Over the last five years, participation in town halls and hearings has exploded because of social media. We organize, we plan, we voice our concerns and we come prepared in absolute opposition to the continuously saying yes to every single apartment complex and up zone. I don't know what it would take. We have voted certain people out and they continue to say yes and put their hand out. I don't know how you stop that. It's a pretty strong effect and problem.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Luxury Apartments and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I think obviously luxury apartments are more desirable to look at and have in your community than cheaper apartments or builder grade everything or government housing. I don't think any of these have a positive effect. None of these things are wanted where I live. So I'm not I'm not really sure how you would improve on that when people don't want this. We prefer single-family homes. I don't know why we can't build normal starter single-family homes like we used to back when boomers were buying homes. Why does everything have to be crammed all together?

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Affordability of Homes on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I don't think anyone believes this is going to make housing more affordable. This is just a lie they tell us to get this stuff passed and pushed through. The reason I say that is because they have built a crap ton of apartment complexes in my county over the past few years, but home prices and apartment rentals have all gone up and property taxes have continued to go up. So they're saying that it's going to affect the affordability of homes in a positive way is not truthful. No one trusts it and it's not going to build support because we know we're being lied to.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Immediate effects and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Immediate effects, if they're positive, probably increase support for upzoning. But overall, I just think it's a negative. It's not something that the suburbs wanted. We don't live in a giant city. We didn't want our suburbs to become that way. So it's a negative effect overall, regardless of how they spin it.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Upzoning support and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I don't understand that question, the relationship between upzoning support and support for upzoning. I guess they're inverse, right? Because people don't want it.

context_qas.question: What do you think are the main causes of Upzoning policies, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
context_qas.answer: I think the main causes are money. They must get a lot of money for the city when they pass this stuff and let these things be built. I don't know what the transparency is on that. I've not looked it up, but I assume there must be a positive for government officials who say yes to this stuff or they wouldn't say yes to everything. Like they live in these communities too. They can drive the streets and see that it's not desirable to have this stuff, so I'm not really sure why all the yes. I'm not sure what is the main cause if not money or gain in some way.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Negative effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Negative effects absolutely lead to less support for upzoning. I'm very confident in that. You know, more traffic, that's a negative. Lessened support. More trash on the roads, potentially more crime. Schools are now too full and so your kid has to go to class in an un-air-conditioned trailer because their school can't hold the number of new, the number of students who've come since we've built all this. Negative effects definitely decrease support. Positive effects would increase support.

context_qas.question: Does Population density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Population density is definitely an issue. I don't see how packing even more people into a smaller area with up zoning is going to help that problem. So I don't really understand why they word it that way. It's not, you know, these people don't live here now. You're building all this stuff to bring them here. I think there's other ways that we could deal with population density and the lack of affordable housing. There's other ways to do this besides this model.

context_qas.question: Does Traffic congestion have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Public opposition lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Increased population density on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

So in that way, it would be a positive effect by decreasing costs. There is no positive effect for costs going up. People are struggling.

context_qas.question: Does Traffic congestion have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Where I live, traffic congestion was already a big problem. It has become a massive problem over the last seven years. They are building tons of apartment complexes, and they are now starting to upzone, like our Costco is upzoning. The effect on traffic congestion is extremely significant. It definitely decreases support for upzoning, I think, for obvious reasons. One of the main reasons.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Local government role and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The relationship between local government and support for upzoning is direct. I feel like there must be kickbacks or something because our local government completely ignores everyone who lives here, every one of our voices. They completely tune us out and they just approve everything. Tons of gas stations, tons of liquor stores, tons of apartment complexes that literally none of us want. It's a pretty strong connection between local government and upzoning support.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Public opposition lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Well, the public are the ones who have to live with these upzoning changes. So if you don't have public support for upzoning, you're going to have public opposition. They are inverse of each other. Make it affordable, somehow decrease traffic, and you would increase public support. But that's not what they're doing. It's going to remain negative.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Increased population density on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I think the effect is pretty immediate. You know, you build 10 apartment complexes, each one holds 200 apartments, and bam, that's all in a three-mile area. Now guess what? People are living there and driving from there. They're all on the roads with us and they weren't here a year ago. That's definitely going to have a negative effect on support. Population density is an issue.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Property taxes and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Strong connection. For sure our property taxes are crazy high. They are building all this crap and our property taxes still go up every year. They haven't lowered them at all even though they're bringing in millions more with all the housing that they've built and filled. It's really not fair and they do nothing about it even though we all do use our voice.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Town hall participation lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: It seems to make no difference. We used to have tiny town hall participation, if they even held town halls. Over the last five years, participation in town halls and hearings has exploded because of social media. We organize, we plan, we voice our concerns and we come prepared in absolute opposition to the continuously saying yes to every single apartment complex and up zone. I don't know what it would take. We have voted certain people out and they continue to say yes and put their hand out. I don't know how you stop that. It's a pretty strong effect and problem.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Luxury Apartments and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I think obviously luxury apartments are more desirable to look at and have in your community than cheaper apartments or builder grade everything or government housing. I don't think any of these have a positive effect. None of these things are wanted where I live. So I'm not I'm not really sure how you would improve on that when people don't want this. We prefer single-family homes. I don't know why we can't build normal starter single-family homes like we used to back when boomers were buying homes. Why does everything have to be crammed all together?

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Affordability of Homes on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I don't think anyone believes this is going to make housing more affordable. This is just a lie they tell us to get this stuff passed and pushed through. The reason I say that is because they have built a crap ton of apartment complexes in my county over the past few years, but home prices and apartment rentals have all gone up and property taxes have continued to go up. So they're saying that it's going to affect the affordability of homes in a positive way is not truthful. No one trusts it and it's not going to build support because we know we're being lied to.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Immediate effects and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Immediate effects, if they're positive, probably increase support for upzoning. But overall, I just think it's a negative. It's not something that the suburbs wanted. We don't live in a giant city. We didn't want our suburbs to become that way. So it's a negative effect overall, regardless of how they spin it.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Upzoning support and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I don't understand that question, the relationship between upzoning support and support for upzoning. I guess they're inverse, right? Because people don't want it.

context_qas.question: What do you think are the main causes of Upzoning policies, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
context_qas.answer: I think the main causes are money. They must get a lot of money for the city when they pass this stuff and let these things be built. I don't know what the transparency is on that. I've not looked it up, but I assume there must be a positive for government officials who say yes to this stuff or they wouldn't say yes to everything. Like they live in these communities too. They can drive the streets and see that it's not desirable to have this stuff, so I'm not really sure why all the yes. I'm not sure what is the main cause if not money or gain in some way.

context_qas.question: Does Population density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Population density is definitely an issue. I don't see how packing even more people into a smaller area with up zoning is going to help that problem. So I don't really understand why they word it that way. It's not, you know, these people don't live here now. You're building all this stuff to bring them here. I think there's other ways that we could deal with population density and the lack of affordable housing. There's other ways to do this besides this model.

task_question: How much do negative effects like traffic and crime affect support for building more housing according to this person?

source_qa.question: How confident are you that changes in Negative effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
source_qa.answer: Negative effects absolutely lead to less support for upzoning. I'm very confident in that. You know, more traffic, that's a negative. Lessened support. More trash on the roads, potentially more crime. Schools are now too full and so your kid has to go to class in an un-air-conditioned trailer because their school can't hold the number of new, the number of students who've come since we've built all this. Negative effects definitely decrease support. Positive effects would increase support.

reasoning: The person clearly states that negative effects like traffic, trash, and crime reduce support for upzoning, indicating a strong negative effect.

context_qas.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
context_qas.answer: to be honest, my main concern is crime.  my family already lives in an area with a higher than average crime rate, and we really do not desire more criminal behavior being brought into the area

context_qas.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
context_qas.answer: on one hand, it helps provide affordable shelter for low income families, but also, it brings criminal behavior into the neighborhood

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
context_qas.answer: I believe that upzoning policies may lower housing costs in urban areas and provide more shelter opportunity for those in need

context_qas.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
context_qas.answer: I believe that criminal culture will become pervasive in neighborhoods where increased housing density is allowed

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
context_qas.answer: I think that upzoning will increase traffic congestion

context_qas.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
context_qas.answer: I believe that local government should weigh the positive and negative consequences for all those individuals involved and should make a decision based upon the greater good

context_qas.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
context_qas.answer: increased urban density is likely to increase carbon output through transportation needs, and should be taken into consideration when deciding to approve

context_qas.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
context_qas.answer: retailers will have more customers, employers may find more workers, which means more tax dollars.  However, wealthier individuals may desire to move out of the neighborhood, leaving their expensive property  and high property tax dollars behind.

context_qas.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
context_qas.answer: the needs of both may contradict each other.  current residents likely may not desire introduction of high density housing for fear of lowering property value, loss of quality of life.  however, future residents may desire affordable housing.  the interests of both parties are valid.  perhaps there is a balance that can be found where both parties can find some room to give a little for the betterment of all.

context_qas.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
context_qas.answer: I do not believe that social equity will be acquired in this life.  however, all citizens of this country should have access to basic needs such as shelter.  therefore, it is the responsibility of all members of the country to sacrifice some in order to ensure the basic needs of all is met

context_qas.question: What causes changes in Support for Upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
context_qas.answer: perhaps when people experience empathy for those in need of housing they experience support for upzoning

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Low Income Families lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am not confident that changes in Low Income Families lead to changes in support for upzoning.  Perhaps, hopefully it would have a positive effect.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Lower housing costs lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I do not believe that small changes would lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning.  maybe, more substantial changes in housing costs would lead to more support for upzoning.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Criminal culture lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that it would take large changes in criminal culture for people to increase support for upzoning

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Traffic Congestion on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: traffic congestion would have an immediate negative effect for support for upzoning

context_qas.question: Does Considering Consequences have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: considering consequences has a negative effect on support for upzoning.  for those living in the proposed neighborhood the effect is strongly negative, for those living outside the neighborhood the effect is mildly positive

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Carbon output lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that it would take larger shifts in carbon output in order to have an effect either positive or negative on support for upzoning

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Higher tax revenue and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that higher tax revenue would have a positive effect for support for upzoning from politicians and citizens at large, however, for current residents in the neighborhood, I do not believe that higher tax revenue will have any effect at all on their negative support for upzoning

context_qas.question: Does Quality of life have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: quality of life will bring empathy and positive support for upzoning from the community, however, the current residents in the neighborhood will consider their negative consequences as having more weight then their sympathy for future residents needs

context_qas.question: Does Balancing interests have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that balancing interests will have a positive effect on support for upzoning as many people will consider it fair for all individuals involved to give a little for the good of others.  the effect will be moderate

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Basic Needs lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am fairly confident that when people realize that the basic need for shelter for people may be met through upzoning, many will people will support upzoning.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Criminal Behavior lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: it will take larger shifts in criminal behavior in order to have a positive effect on support for upzoning

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Low Income Housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am fairly confident that changes in low income housing will lead to positive support for upzoning as long as those changes are substantial

context_qas.answer: my confidence level is certain

context_qas.answer: when upzoning occurs, I believe that crime will surely increase because low income housing almost certainly brings criminal behavior with it.  even if better housing is made available, lower income individuals tend to bring a criminal culture with them.

context_qas.question: What causes changes in Support for Upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
context_qas.answer: perhaps when people experience empathy for those in need of housing they experience support for upzoning

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Low Income Families lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am not confident that changes in Low Income Families lead to changes in support for upzoning.  Perhaps, hopefully it would have a positive effect.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Criminal culture lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that it would take large changes in criminal culture for people to increase support for upzoning

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Traffic Congestion on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: traffic congestion would have an immediate negative effect for support for upzoning

context_qas.question: Does Considering Consequences have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: considering consequences has a negative effect on support for upzoning.  for those living in the proposed neighborhood the effect is strongly negative, for those living outside the neighborhood the effect is mildly positive

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Carbon output lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that it would take larger shifts in carbon output in order to have an effect either positive or negative on support for upzoning

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Higher tax revenue and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that higher tax revenue would have a positive effect for support for upzoning from politicians and citizens at large, however, for current residents in the neighborhood, I do not believe that higher tax revenue will have any effect at all on their negative support for upzoning

context_qas.question: Does Quality of life have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: quality of life will bring empathy and positive support for upzoning from the community, however, the current residents in the neighborhood will consider their negative consequences as having more weight then their sympathy for future residents needs

context_qas.question: Does Balancing interests have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that balancing interests will have a positive effect on support for upzoning as many people will consider it fair for all individuals involved to give a little for the good of others.  the effect will be moderate

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Basic Needs lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am fairly confident that when people realize that the basic need for shelter for people may be met through upzoning, many will people will support upzoning.

context_qas.answer: it will take larger shifts in criminal behavior in order to have a positive effect on support for upzoning

context_qas.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

context_qas.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
context_qas.answer: I believe that local government should weigh the positive and negative consequences for all those individuals involved and should make a decision based upon the greater good

context_qas.answer: increased urban density is likely to increase carbon output through transportation needs, and should be taken into consideration when deciding to approve

context_qas.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
context_qas.answer: retailers will have more customers, employers may find more workers, which means more tax dollars.  However, wealthier individuals may desire to move out of the neighborhood, leaving their expensive property  and high property tax dollars behind.

context_qas.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
context_qas.answer: the needs of both may contradict each other.  current residents likely may not desire introduction of high density housing for fear of lowering property value, loss of quality of life.  however, future residents may desire affordable housing.  the interests of both parties are valid.  perhaps there is a balance that can be found where both parties can find some room to give a little for the betterment of all.

context_qas.question: Does Quality of life have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: quality of life will bring empathy and positive support for upzoning from the community, however, the current residents in the neighborhood will consider their negative consequences as having more weight then their sympathy for future residents needs

context_qas.question: Does Balancing interests have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that balancing interests will have a positive effect on support for upzoning as many people will consider it fair for all individuals involved to give a little for the good of others.  the effect will be moderate

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Basic Needs lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am fairly confident that when people realize that the basic need for shelter for people may be met through upzoning, many will people will support upzoning.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Criminal Behavior lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: it will take larger shifts in criminal behavior in order to have a positive effect on support for upzoning

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Low Income Housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am fairly confident that changes in low income housing will lead to positive support for upzoning as long as those changes are substantial

context_qas.question: What do you think are the main causes of Higher density housing, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
context_qas.answer: my confidence level is certain

source_qa.question: Does Considering Consequences have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

context_qas.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
context_qas.answer: to be honest, my main concern is crime.  my family already lives in an area with a higher than average crime rate, and we really do not desire more criminal behavior being brought into the area

context_qas.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
context_qas.answer: on one hand, it helps provide affordable shelter for low income families, but also, it brings criminal behavior into the neighborhood

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
context_qas.answer: I believe that upzoning policies may lower housing costs in urban areas and provide more shelter opportunity for those in need

context_qas.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
context_qas.answer: I believe that criminal culture will become pervasive in neighborhoods where increased housing density is allowed

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
context_qas.answer: I think that upzoning will increase traffic congestion

context_qas.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
context_qas.answer: I believe that local government should weigh the positive and negative consequences for all those individuals involved and should make a decision based upon the greater good

context_qas.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
context_qas.answer: increased urban density is likely to increase carbon output through transportation needs, and should be taken into consideration when deciding to approve

context_qas.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
context_qas.answer: retailers will have more customers, employers may find more workers, which means more tax dollars.  However, wealthier individuals may desire to move out of the neighborhood, leaving their expensive property  and high property tax dollars behind.

context_qas.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
context_qas.answer: the needs of both may contradict each other.  current residents likely may not desire introduction of high density housing for fear of lowering property value, loss of quality of life.  however, future residents may desire affordable housing.  the interests of both parties are valid.  perhaps there is a balance that can be found where both parties can find some room to give a little for the betterment of all.

context_qas.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
context_qas.answer: I do not believe that social equity will be acquired in this life.  however, all citizens of this country should have access to basic needs such as shelter.  therefore, it is the responsibility of all members of the country to sacrifice some in order to ensure the basic needs of all is met

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Crime and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: when upzoning occurs, I believe that crime will surely increase because low income housing almost certainly brings criminal behavior with it.  even if better housing is made available, lower income individuals tend to bring a criminal culture with them.

context_qas.question: What causes changes in Support for Upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
context_qas.answer: perhaps when people experience empathy for those in need of housing they experience support for upzoning

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Low Income Families lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am not confident that changes in Low Income Families lead to changes in support for upzoning.  Perhaps, hopefully it would have a positive effect.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Lower housing costs lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I do not believe that small changes would lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning.  maybe, more substantial changes in housing costs would lead to more support for upzoning.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Criminal culture lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I believe that it would take large changes in criminal culture for people to increase support for upzoning

task_question: How much does quality of life affect support for building more housing according to this person?

source_qa.question: Does Quality of life have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
source_qa.answer: quality of life will bring empathy and positive support for upzoning from the community, however, the current residents in the neighborhood will consider their negative consequences as having more weight then their sympathy for future residents needs

reasoning: The person believes that quality of life considerations can generate positive support for building more housing, especially from the broader community.

demographics.housing_experience: We actually downsized our house and bought more land. We wanted to get away from the overcrowding that was happening in the town we were in.
demographics.occupation: Service occupations
demographics.financial_situation: I live comfortably but budget carefully
demographics.neighborhood_safety: Somewhat safe – I take normal precautions
demographics.health_insurance: no disability, with private health insurance

context_qas.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
context_qas.answer: I don't feel like they should have higher density housing mixed in with traditional single family neighborhoods. I don't see how mixing the two is good when people are paying a lot of money to live in their own separate houses.

context_qas.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
context_qas.answer: The most significant impact would be negative and that would be too many people in a small area. It causes traffic jams, it causes people to be late for work, it causes more car accidents, more crime. You just can't put a lot of people into a small area.

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
context_qas.answer: It would probably eventually make housing more affordable, but in the area we're in right now, they're still charging ridiculous amounts to pack people in because of greed.

context_qas.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
context_qas.answer: I think the quality of life would go down because nobody's happy being stuffed like sardines into neighborhoods. People are happier when they have places to exercise and stretch their legs and have privacy. I think the character of the neighborhoods might look trashy due to they're so full of people.

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
context_qas.answer: If the cities don't plan ahead and there's not enough ways for people to get in and out of the city, like say only one highway, then there's going to be congestion and transportation is always behind so they won't have anything for the people to use, such as buses or trains. If they could plan that ahead of time, it wouldn't cause a problem.

context_qas.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
context_qas.answer: Local government should definitely step in and make sure that housing development is done properly and safely and up to code and they should also look at the infrastructure of the area to see if it can hold that many people and stop it until it can.

context_qas.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
context_qas.answer: Waste water would be a huge one. All the extra trash and recycling too

context_qas.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
context_qas.answer: The economic effects might be better because there's more people purchasing more things from the stores and the food in the area.

context_qas.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
context_qas.answer: I think the interest of the current residents should be looked at instead of future residents. Future residents are not choosing to live there already.

context_qas.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
context_qas.answer: I'm not sure of this question

context_qas.question: What factors affect Support for Upzoning, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
context_qas.answer: Negative influences would be greed and people wanting to make more money by making housing and not caring about the effects it will have on the people that live there.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Negative Impacts and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I don't think there's a relationship between negative impacts and support for upzoning. The people who support it, well I'm not sure what they want other than affordable housing which would be great, but I'm afraid that's not what they're getting from this.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Traffic Jams on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I feel like this question doesn't make any sense. How can the effect of traffic jams cause for support of upzoning?

context_qas.question: Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Housing affordability is a definite positive side on upzoning. It's just about the only positive effect.

context_qas.question: Does Privacy concerns have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Privacy concerns have a very negative effect on up-zoning. People want to live their lives privately and they cannot do that.

context_qas.question: Does Transportation Systems have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: If there are transportation systems put into effect with the upzoning, that would be very positive and very strong for the environment.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Traffic Congestion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: If traffic congestion could be fixed in upzoning, it would be positive. However, because of the negative sides of too many people with too many cars, it would definitely be a deal breaker for upzoning.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Proper and safe housing development on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Proper and safe housing development is very important for upzoning. It would need to be watched carefully and to code to make sure that if they were going to bring all those people in, it would be in a safe manner.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Urban density lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Small changes in urban density would definitely lead to noticeable changes. It would have maybe a positive effect in the beginning and then lead to a negative effect from overcrowding.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Consumer spending on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The effect of consumer spending would be immediate and it would be positive.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Current residents' interests lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am not confident at all that changes in the current residents' interests would lead to changes in support.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Positive Effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Yes, changes in positive effect would lead to changes in support for upzoning, it would be positive effect.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of People prioritizing profit over community impact on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The effect of people prioritizing profit over community would be very, very negative. It would be immediate.

context_qas.question: What causes changes in Opposition to upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
context_qas.answer: Changes in opposition could be anything from deals made to the community in return for giving up their privacy and properties, or I don't know.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Negative Impacts and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I don't think there's a relationship between negative impacts and support for upzoning. The people who support it, well I'm not sure what they want other than affordable housing which would be great, but I'm afraid that's not what they're getting from this.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Traffic Jams on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I feel like this question doesn't make any sense. How can the effect of traffic jams cause for support of upzoning?

context_qas.question: Does Privacy concerns have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Privacy concerns have a very negative effect on up-zoning. People want to live their lives privately and they cannot do that.

context_qas.question: Does Transportation Systems have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: If there are transportation systems put into effect with the upzoning, that would be very positive and very strong for the environment.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Traffic Congestion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: If traffic congestion could be fixed in upzoning, it would be positive. However, because of the negative sides of too many people with too many cars, it would definitely be a deal breaker for upzoning.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Proper and safe housing development on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Proper and safe housing development is very important for upzoning. It would need to be watched carefully and to code to make sure that if they were going to bring all those people in, it would be in a safe manner.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Urban density lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Small changes in urban density would definitely lead to noticeable changes. It would have maybe a positive effect in the beginning and then lead to a negative effect from overcrowding.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Consumer spending on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The effect of consumer spending would be immediate and it would be positive.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Current residents' interests lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am not confident at all that changes in the current residents' interests would lead to changes in support.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Positive Effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Yes, changes in positive effect would lead to changes in support for upzoning, it would be positive effect.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of People prioritizing profit over community impact on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The effect of people prioritizing profit over community would be very, very negative. It would be immediate.

context_qas.question: What causes changes in Opposition to upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
context_qas.answer: Changes in opposition could be anything from deals made to the community in return for giving up their privacy and properties, or I don't know.

task_question: How much does housing affordability affect support for building more housing according to this person?

source_qa.question: Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
source_qa.answer: Housing affordability is a definite positive side on upzoning. It's just about the only positive effect.

reasoning: The person clearly sees housing affordability as a strong positive influence on support for building more housing.

demographics.occupation: Service occupations
demographics.financial_situation: I live comfortably but budget carefully
demographics.neighborhood_safety: Somewhat safe – I take normal precautions
demographics.health_insurance: no disability, with private health insurance

context_qas.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
context_qas.answer: I don't feel like they should have higher density housing mixed in with traditional single family neighborhoods. I don't see how mixing the two is good when people are paying a lot of money to live in their own separate houses.

context_qas.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
context_qas.answer: The most significant impact would be negative and that would be too many people in a small area. It causes traffic jams, it causes people to be late for work, it causes more car accidents, more crime. You just can't put a lot of people into a small area.

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
context_qas.answer: It would probably eventually make housing more affordable, but in the area we're in right now, they're still charging ridiculous amounts to pack people in because of greed.

context_qas.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
context_qas.answer: I think the quality of life would go down because nobody's happy being stuffed like sardines into neighborhoods. People are happier when they have places to exercise and stretch their legs and have privacy. I think the character of the neighborhoods might look trashy due to they're so full of people.

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
context_qas.answer: If the cities don't plan ahead and there's not enough ways for people to get in and out of the city, like say only one highway, then there's going to be congestion and transportation is always behind so they won't have anything for the people to use, such as buses or trains. If they could plan that ahead of time, it wouldn't cause a problem.

context_qas.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
context_qas.answer: Local government should definitely step in and make sure that housing development is done properly and safely and up to code and they should also look at the infrastructure of the area to see if it can hold that many people and stop it until it can.

context_qas.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
context_qas.answer: Waste water would be a huge one. All the extra trash and recycling too

context_qas.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
context_qas.answer: The economic effects might be better because there's more people purchasing more things from the stores and the food in the area.

context_qas.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
context_qas.answer: I think the interest of the current residents should be looked at instead of future residents. Future residents are not choosing to live there already.

context_qas.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
context_qas.answer: I'm not sure of this question

source_qa.answer: If traffic congestion could be fixed in upzoning, it would be positive. However, because of the negative sides of too many people with too many cars, it would definitely be a deal breaker for upzoning.

reasoning: Although the person acknowledges a potential positive effect if traffic is improved, they believe the negative consequences of increased traffic would outweigh it and reduce support.

demographics.housing_experience: We actually downsized our house and bought more land. We wanted to get away from the overcrowding that was happening in the town we were in.
demographics.occupation: Service occupations
demographics.financial_situation: I live comfortably but budget carefully
demographics.neighborhood_safety: Somewhat safe – I take normal precautions
demographics.health_insurance: no disability, with private health insurance

context_qas.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
context_qas.answer: I don't feel like they should have higher density housing mixed in with traditional single family neighborhoods. I don't see how mixing the two is good when people are paying a lot of money to live in their own separate houses.

context_qas.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
context_qas.answer: The most significant impact would be negative and that would be too many people in a small area. It causes traffic jams, it causes people to be late for work, it causes more car accidents, more crime. You just can't put a lot of people into a small area.

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
context_qas.answer: It would probably eventually make housing more affordable, but in the area we're in right now, they're still charging ridiculous amounts to pack people in because of greed.

context_qas.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
context_qas.answer: I think the quality of life would go down because nobody's happy being stuffed like sardines into neighborhoods. People are happier when they have places to exercise and stretch their legs and have privacy. I think the character of the neighborhoods might look trashy due to they're so full of people.

context_qas.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
context_qas.answer: If the cities don't plan ahead and there's not enough ways for people to get in and out of the city, like say only one highway, then there's going to be congestion and transportation is always behind so they won't have anything for the people to use, such as buses or trains. If they could plan that ahead of time, it wouldn't cause a problem.

context_qas.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
context_qas.answer: Local government should definitely step in and make sure that housing development is done properly and safely and up to code and they should also look at the infrastructure of the area to see if it can hold that many people and stop it until it can.

context_qas.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
context_qas.answer: Waste water would be a huge one. All the extra trash and recycling too

context_qas.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
context_qas.answer: The economic effects might be better because there's more people purchasing more things from the stores and the food in the area.

context_qas.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
context_qas.answer: I think the interest of the current residents should be looked at instead of future residents. Future residents are not choosing to live there already.

context_qas.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
context_qas.answer: I'm not sure of this question

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Single-family neighborhoods on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: It takes time to develop. It has a positive effect eventually.

context_qas.question: What factors affect Support for Upzoning, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
context_qas.answer: Negative influences would be greed and people wanting to make more money by making housing and not caring about the effects it will have on the people that live there.

context_qas.question: How would you describe the relationship between Negative Impacts and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I don't think there's a relationship between negative impacts and support for upzoning. The people who support it, well I'm not sure what they want other than affordable housing which would be great, but I'm afraid that's not what they're getting from this.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Traffic Jams on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I feel like this question doesn't make any sense. How can the effect of traffic jams cause for support of upzoning?

context_qas.question: Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Housing affordability is a definite positive side on upzoning. It's just about the only positive effect.

context_qas.question: Does Privacy concerns have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Privacy concerns have a very negative effect on up-zoning. People want to live their lives privately and they cannot do that.

context_qas.question: Does Transportation Systems have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: If there are transportation systems put into effect with the upzoning, that would be very positive and very strong for the environment.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Traffic Congestion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: If traffic congestion could be fixed in upzoning, it would be positive. However, because of the negative sides of too many people with too many cars, it would definitely be a deal breaker for upzoning.

context_qas.question: Would small changes in Urban density lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Small changes in urban density would definitely lead to noticeable changes. It would have maybe a positive effect in the beginning and then lead to a negative effect from overcrowding.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of Consumer spending on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The effect of consumer spending would be immediate and it would be positive.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Current residents' interests lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: I am not confident at all that changes in the current residents' interests would lead to changes in support.

context_qas.question: How confident are you that changes in Positive Effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: Yes, changes in positive effect would lead to changes in support for upzoning, it would be positive effect.

context_qas.question: Is the effect of People prioritizing profit over community impact on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
context_qas.answer: The effect of people prioritizing profit over community would be very, very negative. It would be immediate.

context_qas.question: What causes changes in Opposition to upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
context_qas.answer: Changes in opposition could be anything from deals made to the community in return for giving up their privacy and properties, or I don't know.
